A description of a protein's modification status (e.g, if it was mutated, post-translationally modified etc.). If a DNA vector was used to express the modified protein in a cell line, a description of the DNA vector needs to be provided (see below).
column20: If available

column18: A description of a protein's level of purity (e.g., if it was partially purified, purified, unpurified, etc.)
column20: This can't be a required field as this information is not always provided by the vendor.

column18: The description of a macromolecular complex composed of two or more polypeptide subunits, which may or may not be identical. The individual subunits should be described as being part of a protein complex (e.g. heterotrimer of alpha, beta and gamma subunits), the name of the protein complex, individual subunit protein name, protein ID, gene name and gene ID.
column20: If a protein complex is described and given a single LINCS ID, information about each subunit will have to be provided (e.g the entry will have multiple UniProt Ids associated with it).

column18: This describes whether the protein is an isoform and differs from the initial protein due to either alternative splicing, alternative initiation or ribosomal frameshifting during translation. The isoforms have different protein sequences and hence different protein IDs, though they share the same gene ID.
column20: This can't be a required field as this information is not always provided by the vendor.

column18: A controlled vocabulary, if one exists, specifying whether the protein is a growth factor, peptide, protein, etc.
column20: The vocabulary here is important; it gets fuzzy as what is a growth factor vs. a cytokine. This can be made unambiguous by describing these concepts as a role of a protein, whether it functions as a 'ligand: growth factor' or a 'ligand: cytokine'. We agree that this seems important, but no good ontology of protein types exists and so categorizing proteins by type is a very subjective exercise now.

column18: A controlled vocabulary describing the source of the protein (e.g. mouse, rabbit, horse, goat, etc.)

The primary name of the antibody as chosen by LINCS
Unique identifier of antibody reagent
List of synonymous antibody names, including the primary name
Center specific ID for antibody
The name of the protein (target), which is the recommended name from the UniProt database. If the name of a related entity is used instead, this should be documented explicitly in AR_Immunogen.
The UniProt ID of the protein targeted by the antibody, if available. If the UniProt ID of a related entity is used instead, this should be documented explicitly.
The NCBI gene name. In cases where the protein is modified (the protein sequence differs from the sequence encoded by the gene listed), it should be described in AR_Immunogen.
Entrez Gene ID if using NCBI gene name
The organism of the target protein/gene described in AR:7-AR:10; NCBI nomenclature (e.g. Homo sapiens).

A complete description of the immunogen used to make the antibody (text). This description should include the source of the immunogen (e.g. recombinantly expressed in E. coli, purified from canine pancreas, etc.). Any references relevant to the immunogen or making of the antibody can be listed in AR_Relevant_Reference.
If the immunogen is a peptide, protein fragment, or small protein, the amino acid sequence should be provided.
A controlled vocabulary specifying whether the antibody is polyclonal or monoclonal.
A controlled vocabulary describing the source of the antibody (e.g. mouse, rabbit, horse, goat, etc.)
A controlled vocabulary describing the antibody isotype (e.g. IgG, IgM, etc.)

Is the antibody engineered/produced in an animal? Yes/No. If yes, then information should be provided about the engineering method and the production method (produced in mammalian cells, insect cells, yeast, bacteria, etc.).
A description of the antibody's level of purity (e.g., if it was purified, affinity purified, etc.)--a controlled vocabulary should be developed.
It should be indicated (Yes/No) whether the antibody is labeled or conjugated; If yes, with what fluor or enzyme (horseradish peroxidase)

The type of experiment in which the antibody is useful, e.g., western blot, ELISA, immunostaining, etc. This depends on the ability of the antibody to recognize the native (non-denatured) or denatured target protein.
Appropriate literature references can be provided.

Proteins other than the intended target with which the antibody cross-reacts. This includes homologues of the target protein from other organisms (text field; appropriate references should be provided if available).
